answers.answer: Hi, understand your anxiety. Your mother in law has  many clinical conditions and any of them could be causing the hypoxia to the heart muscle. Another issue could be stroke, this can cause diminished blood supply to vital centres in the brain and consequent problems with breathing. Discuss in detail with her treating doctor, you may gain more insight. Good luck with her therapy. Regards.

question: Hello, my mother in law has been through a ton of health scares in her life. She survived breast cancer 20 yrs ago..... chain smoked up to 2-3 packs a day for probably 35 yrs.  About 7 yrs. ago she had kidney problems and went to the ER and they noticed her heart was terrible.  She ended up having a quadruple bypass.  She quit smoking cold turkey.  The past 1 1/2 yrs she has been in terrible shape.  She has literally died 3 times, has had 4 heart attacks.  They finally diagnosed her with COPD and CHF (She has also been a diabetic for a few years).  This last exacerbation she experienced was a doozy.  She was in a med induced coma for a couple days, life support ect.  They had to do hypothermic therapy on her to preserve brain function.  She baffled Dr.'s and nurses and is awake, alert, eating, can get out of her hospital bed and into recliner.  What happens is scary.  She will be fine....feeling "normal" and all of the sudden out of the blue, she can't breathe (at home).  She has been picked up from her home by ambulance about 4 times in the past 4 months....in and out of hospitals and nursing homes.  She now lives in a state of total anxiety because she never knows when it will hit.  I am wondering how much more this woman can handle.  Dr's and nurses are (I think) afraid to tell us their opinion...their job is to give us hope and that's great....but watching her constantly go through this is heart wrenching.  How many heart attacks can someone handle?
title: MIL with CHF/COPD/Diabetes
